awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CDS&E: Constraining the uncertain physics of galaxy formation: cosmic rays, black holes, and beyond
awd_abstract_narration:
Computer simulations of galaxy formation are powerful tools to help understand, test, and predict the observed properties of galaxies in the local and extremely distant Universe. Given the large number of sensitive wide-area galaxy surveys that have recently started (or are soon to be underway) there is a critical need for simulations that model the formation and evolution of galaxies with the highest accuracy. The proposed research will build upon the group’s earlier transformative galaxy simulations by adding the effects of gas accretion onto massive black holes, extremely high energy atomic nuclei (cosmic rays), and magnetic fields. These efforts will additionally train graduate and undergraduate students, mentor area high school students, and produce animations for public shows. The team will continue an educational program for prison inmates.

This research represents the further development of a project started several years ago by the FIRE (Feedback in Realistic Environments) collaboration to create state-of-the-art hydrodynamic simulations of galaxy formation and evolution that included a detailed treatment of “feedback” from massive stars and supernovae. That work successfully reproduced a wide range of observed galaxy properties – masses, chemical abundances trends, and scaling relations – for dwarf galaxies up to approximately Milky Way sized (L*) systems. For more massive galaxies, an accurate treatment of the energy injected by rapidly accreting massive black holes (i.e., active galactic nuclei; AGN) is required. This is one of the primary updates to the original FIRE simulation code proposed here. Other potentially important processes, including magnetic fields and cosmic rays, and a new framework to track chemical abundances are to be implemented as well. These promise to result in new galaxy simulations with parsec-scale resolution that are more accurate and that allow predictions (i.e., “forward modeling”) for a wide range of physical phenomena, including resolved radio and gamma-ray emission, cosmic ray spectra, Faraday rotation in and around galaxies, the Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect, and the dynamics of the circum-galactic medium. The FIRE team will make publicly available to the scientific community new modules for the GIZMO simulation code developed as part of this work, as well as data products from the project. In the area of Broader Impacts this project will support four graduate students, a dozen undergraduate students, and a number of high-school students involved in creating scientific animations. The team will also engage inmates in educational activities via a partnership with the Stateville Correctional Center.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported a large program developing and analyzing state-of-the-art computer simulations of galaxies, in order to understand basic questions like: How does the Universe go from the Big Bang to galaxies like the our own Milky Way today? Why do galaxies look and behave as they do? What can the structure of galaxies tell us about fundamental physics at high energies and plasma physics processes which we cannot hope to model in conditions in our laboratories? What can we learn about the nature of the dark matter from these probes (the source of our best measurements and constraints on the properties of the elusive dark matter)? Why did the Universe turn such a small fraction of its matter into stars, and where is this "missing matter"? What are the origins and properties of the giant "super-massive" black holes living in galaxy centers, and how do they "communicate" with their galaxies on larger scales to correlate so tightly with their properties? And how to explosions of massive stars provide the heavy elements we see and shape galaxies.

To explore this, we developed novel computer models through our Feedback In Realistic Environments (FIRE) project, including all of the physics above for the first time in simulations which follow the formation of galaxies "end to end" from the early Universe to today. The simulations allow us to add or remove more speculative pieces of physics (e.g. different models for the dark matter particle), or even to remove physics we know must be present (e.g. the influence of magnetic fields on charged particles in the galaxy), in order to make clear, testable predictions for current and upcoming astrophysics observatories and space telescopes. We analyzed these simulations across our large network of theory collaborators: FIRE is one of the largest theory collaborations in astrophysics, spanning more than 20 different institutions in the United States (and several in Canada and Europe), with more than 100 scientists, including a large number of advanced undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral scholars, and academic faculty.

With the support from this grant these new physics were included into our core simulation code, new enormous libraries of simulations were run, these simulations were analyzed and compared to observations, and new constraints and measurements and insights emerged. We showed for the first time that certain types of dark matter previously thought to be ruled-out could in fact be hiding in plain sight, while other types of dark matter models were strongly ruled out by observations that had not previously been thought to constrain the dark matter. We showed how "feedback" processes like supernova explosions and winds from black holes swallowing gas could shape galaxies and explain decades-old problems in astrophysics, but their predictions were very sensitive to the physical carriers of the energy in the feedback. We showed that the "conventional wisdom" for how protons moving near the speed of light in galaxies (cosmic rays) interact with galactic magnetic fields was fundamentally incompatible with observations, and outlined the fundamental assumptions of those textbook models that must be broken to reconcile this, likely telling us fundamental things about the nature of space plasmas and their turbulence.

We made all of the code developed for this project, and a library of the simulations themselves, public. This has already been used by dozens of other groups across astrophysics, in hundreds of papers, to extend and broaden the reach of these developments.

We also mentored a large group of students. Several undergraduate students were trained and mentored and completed research projects with the PI over summers and as part of their undergraduate theses. Several graduate students were recruited and used these simulations and code-building as the core of their Ph.D. theses. Several postdoctoral fellows were supported and trained as next-generation leaders in building and analyzing their own simulation models. Thousands of members of the public and hundreds of high school students were brought in through a creative outreach and visualization program, involving using these simulations to build interactive visualizations for public lectures, movies, and planetarium shows, uniquely leveraging the visual medium of the simulations and astronomy.
